titlestmt.titleproper: Gordon Zahorik collection, Inclusive: 1939-1980, undated, Bulk: 1939-1947

note.p: Â© 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Gordon Zahorik collection contains photographs of streetcars operated by the Texas Electric Railway Company during the 1930's and 1940's.

originalsloc.head: Originals/Duplicates
originalsloc.p: Mix of some originals and some copies.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The railroad proved to be integral to the development and urbanization of Central Texas, particularly in the case of Waco. Interurban lines were established in Dallas, Waco, and other cites to aid the flow of commercial goods and passengers. In 1917, the Texas Electric Railway Company was formed through a merging of the Southern Traction and Texas Traction Companies.

Following World War II, with the rise in automobile sales and the creation of the interstate highway system, railroads no longer served as the primary means of public transportation. On December 31, 1948, the Texas Electric Railway Company ceased streetcar operations in Waco.

Gordon Zahorik, the creator of this collection, was an avid photographer and train enthusiast. A veteran of the U.S. Army, Zahorik served during World War II from 1943 to 1946. He resided in the Robinson area and was vocal about Waco's need for a strong public transportation system. He passed away in Lorena, Texas, at the age of 75 on April 16, 2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of approximately 45 photographs of Texas Electric Railway Company streetcars ranging in date from 1939 to 1947, a train schedule from 1948, and a 1980 clipping from the Waco-Tribune Herald containing biographical information about Gordon Zahorik.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Gordon Zahorik collection was initially arranged as a single folder of photographs. The time card and the newspaper clipping regarding Gordon Zahorik were originally located in the control file.

The collection is now arranged into seven folders and two series according to material type. Series I. Literary Productions is comprised of the time card and clipping. Series II. Photographic Materials constitutes the bulk of the collection. The photographs have been organized according to the terminal from which the railway cars were operating.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gordon Zahorik collection, Accession #284, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Thomas DeShong. Released on 2017-03-03.

relatedmaterial.head: Related references
relatedmaterial.bibref: Hunt, Alan. "Streetcar Buff Proposes New Waco Line." Waco-Tribune Herald, 1980 March 27.

bibref.extref: Ryan, Terri Jo. "Interurban Railway." Waco History.org. Accessed 2017 February 16.
Webb, Walter Prescott. "Interurban Line." In Handbook of Waco and McLennan County Texas. Edited by Dayton Kelley. Waco: Texian Press, 1972.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Literary Productions series is comprised of two items. The newspaper clipping by Alan Hunt provides some biographical information about Gordon Zahorik, the creator of the collection. The time card, produced by the Texas Electric Railway Company, details train arrivals and departures for the Dallas-Denison and Dallas-Waco lines in 1948. The materials in this series are in excellent condition.

did.unittitle: Clipping: Waco-Tribune Herald: "Streetcar Buff Proposes New Waco Line": Alan Hunt
Time Card: Texas Electric Railway Company: Dallas-Waco Division and Dallas-Denison Division

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Series II. Photographic Materials contains approximately 45 photographs of streetcars operating on the Texas Electric Railway from 1939 to 1947. The photographs have been arranged according to the terminal from which the cars were operating including Dallas, Waco, and Hillsboro. The photographs in this series are in excellent condition.
